titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. There was little business done in the Senate, and they adjourned early. Met Mr: Smith of Maryland and Mr: Gilman, on a Committee to whom was referr’d a petition from two persons by the name of Chase and Gardner at Nantucket— After some conversation it was agreed that I should call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for some papers in the case— Mr: Quincy asked me to have some conversation with him, which I did at his chamber— He enquired into the motives of my late conduct in Congress, which I fully detailed to him— He said my principles were too pure for those with whom I was acting—and they would not thank me for them— I told him I did not want their thanks— He said they would not value me the more for them— I told him, I cared not whether they valued me for them or not— My character such as it was must stand upon its own ground, and not upon the bolstering of any man or party— I fully opened to him my motives for supporting the Administration at this Crisis, and my sense of the danger which a Spirit of opposition at this time is bringing upon the Union. I told him where that opposition in case of War must in its nature end— Either in a Civil War—or in a dissolution of the Union with the Atlantic States in subserviency to Great-Britain— That to resist this I was ready if necessary to sacrifice every thing I have in life, and even life itself— I intimated to him that he would be called perhaps ere long to make the election which side he would take too— He said he did not see the prospect in the same light, but if he did, he should also be willing to meet that question when it came— He did not say which side he should take— The result of the Conversation was an opinion on my part that he was too far pledged in opposition to retreat, and that his own idea was rather that of reclaiming me from the “error of my ways”— We must wait with patience, to see where the right is.— I spent the Evening at Dr: Thornton’s with a large party— Had a long Conversation with Mr: Casamajor, on the differences now in negotiation between Great-Britain, and us. Had also some conversation with Mr: Rose; whom Mr: Erskine formally introduced to me the second time.

2. Met with Mr: Giles’s Committee, at ten this morning— He had a bill drawn, but was waiting for copies to be made out for the members— We made some progress in discussing its various Sections, and adjourned untill Thursday morning, with the view of attending the Senate— But they too had met and adjourned— I now pointedly asked Mr: Giles, whether he thought that sort of negotiation, of Mr: Bayard, on personal considerations for himself, and local advantages for his State, was a sound course of proceeding on moral and political principle— Giles evaded answering this question— He said
that nothing had ever pass’d between them which could properly be termed a negotiation— That Bayard had been he believed more explicit with Genl: Smith— That in his Conversations with him, the most particular of which was last Spring, at Daniel Clark’s Ball, he had indeed intimated a wish to coalesce with the administration, always connected with some views of personal aggrandizement for himself— He had said there were no prospects for him under this Administration— That Mr: Jefferson hated federalists— But he hoped a new State of things would come with which he could be reconciled— A War, for instance— And within a few days he has suggested the same thing, with regard to Mr: Madison’s Election.— I did tell him said Mr: Giles, that if he could find the views of public affairs of the Administration such as he could cordially support, he might remove his residence to Philadelphia, and would very soon be at the head of the Pennsylvania delegation, which might place him in that rank and consideration to which he thinks himself entitled— I then observed to Mr: Giles that as, from some observations he had made to me at our last Conversation, I had supposed he might intend that I should apply to myself some intimations of a similar nature, I thought myself bound to be very explicit with him— That in any support I have given or ever shall give to this or any other administration I have been and shall be governed solely by public considerations, and the belief that the Administration aims at the welfare of the Nation.— That I have no personal expectations or wishes whatsoever— He replied that he had often been asked by his friends in Virginia respecting me; and had uniformly told them that he believed I considered every public measure as I should a proposition in Euclid, abstracted from any party considerations, and that was the reason why he thought that since we have been together in Senate there were perhaps no two members who so often voted together as him and me. There was a good deal more of conversation between us, but none which I deem it now necessary to write down— It was on my part entirely without reference to myself—on his it had possibly some meaning.— He said he believed the present Vice-President would serve again in that Office— But if he did not, he should have no objection to select an Eastern Gentleman— That as to DeWitt Clinton, who was said to be the greatest political intriguer in the United States, nothing could induce him (Giles) to support his pretensions.— That Mr: Lewis the late Governor of New-York was expected here in a day or two, though he did not know for what— That with respect to Mr: Madison’s election, he had no personal views of his own to promote— That he had never said a word to Mr: Madison about it; for he should have thought it indelicate— And he believed the same of Coll: Nicholas— The result of the whole Conversation in my mind is this—Giles and Nicholas are the managers for Madison’s election, in the two houses.— Giles has been working with me and with Bayard, much in the same way.— Opening to our view personal expectations and flattering prospects to engage us with them.— Bayard who (as I told Giles) lacks advancement has more than met him half-way, and will eventually make his bargain.— Giles was somewhat unexpectedly met, and probably not well pleased with my direct and explicit denial of any personal views, by which any Administration could take hold of me— But he still perseveres in touching strings, which he thinks will vibrate internally for his purposes.— Giles understands his business— And it is no small part of his address to manage as he does his political coquetting between Bayard and me— By setting us upon one another, he is sure to draw strength from our weakness.— This also explains to me that bitter and unrelenting virulence with which Bayard is always seeking opposition to me— He thinks to recommend himself to Giles, by his virulence against me— Giles’s conversations have clearly shewn his motives— I had been much surprized at it before, and found it utterly unaccountable.— I intimated something of this opinion to Giles, and he assented to it— Bayard formerly carried on the same struggle against Giles himself— But since Giles has been in such a triumphant majority that is ever since we have all been in Senate together, Bayard has invariably cowered before Giles, and sought his consolation in pecking at me— — — I spent the Evening with the family at Mr: Erskine’s where there was a Ball.— I attended a few minutes this morning in the Supreme Court.

3. There was some business done this day in Senate, and five Committees raised—but very little debate— Adjourned about one O’Clock— I was employed in writing letters to Governor Sullivan, and to Mr: Ewing at Philadelphia— The House of Representatives were engaged in discussing a motion of Mr: Sloan for removing the seat of Government—a very inflammatory subject— I spent the Evening at home, in regret at my own want of temper— This morning I called at the Treasury Office for the papers relating to the petition of Chase and Gardner, which Mr: Sheldon promised to send me— I afterwards met Mr: Gallatin the Secretary of the Treasury, who told me his reasons for having suspended his decision upon the case, which had occasioned their application to Congress.

4. Met Mr: Giles’s Committee, on the Amendment of the penal Laws.— We agreed to report one Bill, (in part) and reserve another part of the subject for further enquiry.— That part relating to Evidence, remains still to be acted upon.— The Senate met and adjourned while we were sitting in Committee— We sat untill near four O’Clock in the afternoon— I then went into the house, where I found them taking the yeas and nays on the question for committing to a Committee of the whole, Mr: Sloan’s motion to remove the Seat of Government— It was refused 63. to 61. And the House immediately adjourned— I rode to the Capitol this morning with Mr: Eppes.— Spent the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s— He was not at home— Mr: Sheldon there.

5. Met this morning three Committees, and agreed to their reports— One, on an application from Mr: Latrobe the Architect— One on the Naval Appropriation Bill— And one on the Bill to erect a light-house upon Point Judith—Rhode-Island.— The reports were made and acted upon in Senate— Mr: Giles’s Bill was also reported, and pass’d to the second reading— Dr: Mitchill presented a Yazoo petition, from New-York— Mitchill has always before been on the other side of this question— The Georgia members objected against receiving the petition, upon which a debate arose, and the question was taken by yeas and nays 22. to 3. The members from Georgia and Mr: Moore of Virginia, alone voting against receiving it— Mr: Giles supported them in a speech, but left his seat apparently to avoid voting— I supported the reception of this petition because I know that those people are suffering Injustice, and think that they ought to have Justice done them— But this particular petition I consider as an electioneering manoeuvre of the Clinton party; and it will embarrass the supporters of Mr: Madison— I went into the House, but found they had adjourned. Mr: Sloan had withdrawn his motion—which was succeeded by several counter-motions upon which no decision was taken.— Mr: R. Smith the Secretary of the Navy sent me to the Capitol this morning— Spent the Evening in my chamber at home.

6. The Senate, yesterday adjourned over to Monday; and this being the first leisure Saturday which I have had, for seven weeks, I employed the morning, principally in retrieving some arrears into which my customary labours of minor urgency had run— Called at the Secretary of State’s Office, with the letter from Mr: Loud of Weymouth— Mr: Madison informed me that he had received and answered an application upon the same subject— Dined with Genl: Turreau the french Minister— There were about twenty persons at table— Members of Congress and others— Among the rest, Mr: Madison— Spent the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s— He was not himself at home— Dr: Weems was there part of the Evening— Conversation with him respecting Mr: John Randolph, who is ill at Mr: Key’s—from a fall in which he received a very violent Strain— Randolph it appears has been very communicative with him, upon political affairs.

7. The foulness of the weather, and the depth of the roads confined me the whole of this day to the house— I answered Mr: Loud—and wrote long letters to my brother, and to Jos: Hall.— My business multiplies upon me to such a degree, that I must select and discard some of it, and methodize my occupations more than heretofore— Mr: Boyd spent the Evening with us.

8. In Senate, Mr: Giles’s Bill was read the second time, and made the order of the day, to be considered as in Committee of the whole on Thursday. Two or three Bills were pass’d without a question or observation, and soon after noon, they adjourned, for want of having any business to transact.— I called the Committee on the Petition of Chase and Gardner of Nantucket, who agreed that I should draw a Report and ask leave to bring in a Bill for the relief of the petitioners.— I afterwards went into the House of Representatives where they are still debating on the proposition for removing the seat of Government— They left it still undecided— Rode home in a Snow-Storm— Evening wasted in reading newspapers.

9. There was no business to do in Senate, and they adjourned between twelve and one. I drew a Report and a Bill for the Committee on the petition of Jos: Chase and Jared Gardner, which I submitted to the other members of the Committee—Smith of Maryland, and Gilman; they agreed to it, and it is to be reported to-morrow— I returned the visit of Messrs: Apthorp, Amory, Lee and Richards, the last only of whom I found at their lodgings— I went into the House, where I found them debating on the non-importation Act, the Supplementary Bill— The Speaker introduced Mr: Bacon to me— I had some further conversation with Mr. Dana— Mr: Anderson told me there was last Evening a meeting of the federal members.— Evening, arranging papers.

10. Saw this morning on my way to the Capitol Mr: T. C. Amory, with Mr: Deblois of Alexandria— And at the Capitol Mr: Apthorp and Mr Richards.— Also Mr: Story of Salem, who was introduced to me by Mr: Bacon.— In Senate, I made a report, and presented a Bill, in the case of Joseph Chase and Jared Gardner.— The Bill pass’d to a second reading— Mr: Milledge introduced a Bill for erecting a light-house in Georgia.— Scarcely any other business done— And several members absent. Dr: Mitchill introduced to me a Mr: David C. Wallace, one of the witnesses on Burr’s trial at Richmond, and just from Chillicothe.— I was a few minutes in the House of Representatives, where they pass’d the bill supplementary to the non-importation Act.— Mr: and Mrs: Boyd spent the Evening with us below.

11. Mr: Giles’s penal Bill was made the order of this day and was taken up as in Committee of the whole— An Amendment to the first Section was proposed by Mr: Bayard, and adopted— Dr: Mitchill moved to strike out the first Section, which he supported by a short Speech— Mr: Giles made a long and very powerful speech in its support, and the Senate adjourned— There was company at dinner at Mr: Hellen’s— Mr: and Mrs: Erskine, and a number of Gentlemen— Mr: Casamajor the elder pass’d the Evening here— Mrs: Johnson and the young Ladies went to the Ball.

12. Mr: Giles’s Bill was postponed without any discussion upon it, untill the 16th:— My Bill in favour of Jos: Chase, and Jared Gardner & others pass’d without opposition— A Bill Supplementary to the Non-importation Act, at the second reading was referr’d to a Select Committee— Senate adjourned early, untill Monday— Evening at home.

13. Mrs: Hellen gave me a seat to the Capitol, where I met the Committee on the Bill supplementary to the non-importation Act. Mr: Smith of Maryland (Chairman) and Mr: Mitchill were the other members— Mr: Newton, the Chairman of the Committee of Commerce and Manufactures was with us, and proposed the introduction of several amendments, which he had not had time to carry through the house, before the Bill pass’d there— But we did not agree to them.— We determined to report the Bill without Amendment— There were at the Capitol several members of both Houses; and Mr: Giles appeared much exasperated at a threat which has appeared from Mr: Monroe, of publishing another Book.— An Electioneering Book, to defeat Madison’s Election & promote his own— Giles says he told Mr: Jefferson it would end in that, long since; and that he would after his return home pursue a course of conduct which would lead to his own destruction, or to that of the Administration— Mr: Cook, of the House of Representatives, asked me for some private conversation— And then told me that many of the eastern members were disgusted at the state of degradation and oppression in which the interests of that part of the Country was kept, by these negro-votes (as he called them.) He said that Mr: Story was here; and very much hurt at the refusal of the house yesterday to hear him as Counsel for the Yazoo Claimants. And he ask’d me, what was to be done?— I told him that before any thing could be done by way of concerted operation for retrieving that weight in the national Councils, to which we were justly entitled, it would be necessary that we should understand one another, and be sure that we could harmonize among ourselves— That I had little intimacy with the members of his general political opinions— That our weakness was the necessary consequence of our divisions— That unless these could be healed it was idle to think of attempting any thing— That if a disposition to that object existed I should be glad to contribute my aid, for effecting it; and I should readily converse with any Gentlemen who wished it, on the subject— He said he would commit to paper his ideas and mention there the names of the Gentlemen whose co-operation to that end might be relied on— If this matter should be pursued any further I shall be very cautious how I proceed— The object and tendency of the thing is not yet sufficiently apparent— I see enough however to put me upon my guard— Il faut voir venir— I attended a short time in the Supreme Court, where all the judges were present—hearing Mr: Martin.— Evening at home.
14. Attended church at the Capitol with Catherine and Adelaide Johnson— Heard Mr: M’Cormick— Visits from Mr: Verplanck and his son— Mr: Mansfield, Mr: Duer, and Mr: Metarby.

15. A Petition from the Cherokee Indians to the President of the United States, was read in the Senate, to whom a copy had been transmitted, lest the original to the Executive should not arrive— After it was read—I moved to go into Executive business, to consider it; where it was referr’d to a select Committee— Scarcely any other business done— Mr: Bradley told me he had a letter from Boston which mentioned that the federalists in Massachusetts would acquiesce in the nomination of Mr: Madison as President; but not in that of Mr: Clinton as Vice-President— That they would prefer Mr: Langdon— I doubt the correctness of this information— I spent the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: Casamajor and Mr: Duer were there.

16. Mr: Giles’s penal bill was further postponed untill Thursday next— A bill for altering the Law of the last Session, establishing the seventh judicial Circuit was taken up as in Committee of the whole and after some remarks postponed untill to-morrow, at my request— Mr: Giles proposed a Resolution for the appointment of a Committee to enquire whether the Supreme Court have authority to issue writs of Habeas Corpus &c.—the consideration of this motion was also postponed at my request.— I dined at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: George Johnson, and a Mr: Robinson was there— Evening with my wife and Mr: Hellen’s family at Mr: Erskine’s— Cards part of the Evening— Some conversation with Mr: Cook,—and with the late Governor Lewis, of New-York— The rumours of Mr: Rose’s departure are revived.

17. The Seventh Circuit judicial Bill was taken up, and after a debate of about three hours referr’d again to the Committee who reported it, with the addition of two members.— There was little other business done in Senate— Adjourned about 8— There was a Ball this Evening at Dr: Ewell’s, at the Navy-Yard, which the family attended— But Mrs: Adams being unwell, we remained at home.

18. The Committee on Mr: Tiffin’s seventh Circuit Judicial Bill met this morning— Mr: Tiffin, Mr: Anderson, Mr: Bradley and myself attended. Mr: Pope, the other member was absent— The Committee agreed to report that the first and third Sections should be struck out.— Mr: Anderson, Mr: Smith of Tennessee, and myself also met on the Bill making appropriations for the Indian Treaties, and agreed to report it without amendment— In Senate, the Treason Bill was again postponed untill next Monday— Mr: Giles’s motion for a Committee to enquire whether the Supreme Court have power to issue writs of Habeas Corpus, was considered, and after some debate adopted with an Amendment proposed by me— Met the Committee on the Resolution for selling the North Carolina Charts— I am to call at the Treasury Office on the subject— I was a few minutes in the house of Representatives— Evening at home— Mr: Duer was here a couple of hours with Catherine Johnson from Mr: Boyd’s— Music below— The weakness of my eyes compels me to waste many Evenings, and takes necessarily much of my time from the public business.

19. Met the Committee on the Bill for the relief of Samuel Whiting— (Bradley and White.) We examined the papers, and agreed to report the Bill without Amendment— There was some debate in the Senate upon an Amendment to a bill for importing old copper duty-free— The Amendment proposes to liberate salt-petre and sulphur also from duty— No decision on the question— Mr: Smith of Maryland called together again the Committee on the Bill supplementary to the non-importation-act; to propose some Amendments desired by the Secretary of the Treasury.— The Committee agreed to report them— I went into the House and heard a debate, on the third embargo-bill— Left it undecided— Spent the Evening with my wife at Mr: Boyd’s— Mrs: Johnson and Adelaide were there— Bad walking.

20. Called at the Office of the Secretary of the Navy, to enquire for Mr: English, whether his nephew, now at sea, might receive his warrant as a Midshipman, after his return home—the Secretary consented— I found Mr: Erskine with him— He went out while I was there— Mr: Smith said they were negotiating—directly and indirectly— I told him I had heard all negotiation was at an end— He replied—Not altogether— I called also at the Secretary of the Treasury’s Office, but he was not there— It was to make inquiries respecting a Resolution to sell, certain Charts of North-Carolina Coast, taken by order of Congress.— Mr: Sheldon gave me some information upon the subject— I attended at the Capitol, to meet Mr: Giles’s Habeas-Corpus Committee, but he sent word that he could not attend— I wrote to Mr: English— Returned Mr: Dawson’s visit— Went into the House of Representatives, where I heard the close of a very vehement and inflammatory Speech of Mr: Gardenier; on the question for recommitting at the third reading a bill supplementary to the Embargo— The House adjourned without taking a question—but with some threats of calling Gardenier to account for his words— I attended a few minutes in the Supreme Court— L. Martin was speaking.— Evening at home, reading the pamphlet called the British Treaty.

21. Devoted the morning to attendance at Church, in Georgetown, and heard Mr: Sayrs— Visit afterwards to Mr: Söderström. Mr: and Mrs: Boyd, and Catherine, Dined and pass’d the Evening here— Mr: Casamajor the younger, and Mr: Duer were also here at supper— My leisure time, from noon, was thus occupied altogether by Company.

22. In Senate— Mr: Giles’s penal bill was again taken up for consideration— The yeas and nays were called upon the motion to strike out the first Section— I then moved the recommitment of the Bill, and spoke at some length upon this question— But pitched my voice too high, and broke it, untill I made myself very hoarse— Mr: Hillhouse seconded my motion; but made a speech against mine— Mr: Giles, Mr: Pope and Mr: Anderson took also some part in the debate; and the Senate adjourned without taking the question— There was a Ball in the Evening at Stelle’s, which the ladies of our family excepting Mrs: Adams, attended— There was also a Ball at George-town— Both, in celebration of Washington’s Birth-day.

23. On taking my seat in Senate this morning, I found a Philadelphia News-paper of the 19th: (Jackson’s political Register) directed to me, and laid on my table; containing a letter from this place, full of falsehoods, and abuse against me, by name— The writer insinuates that he is a member of Congress; and refers to Mr: Lewis, a member from Virginia, for his name upon certain conditions— But the charges against me, are merely of a ridiculous character, and in every particular stated as fact, false— The object of the writer is obviously to get himself into notice, by seeking a controversy with me— I had some doubts whether I should not call upon Lewis, for the writer’s name— But concluded, after some reflection that it would be giving him too much consequence— The danger of once undertaking to answer newspaper falsehoods, is of involving yourself in a sort of obligation always to answer, which would be endless— On consulting Mr: Anderson, he concurr’d entirely in this opinion— There was little business done in Senate. Mr: Giles’s bill was postponed untill to-morrow— Our Ladies all attended the party at Mr: Erskine’s this Evening— I did not go.

24. I received this morning letters from my father and mother— I answered the last, immediately— These letters contain a test for my firmness—for my prudence; and for my filial reverence— May I be assisted to stand this test, without impairing either of those duties!— In Senate, the principal business was the discussion of Mr: Giles’s Bill— Mr: Pope made a long and eloquent Speech against it— Mr: Crawford spoke in its support.— Dined with my wife and child at Mr: Boyd’s— In the Evening a Mr: Schwarz was there with a very beautiful copy in Crayons of a Madona from Raphaël— Returning home we got nearly overset in the Carriage— And bewildered for some time in the fields— We however reached home safe at last.

25. There was a debate in Senate, on a question for taking off the duties from salt-petre and sulphur— An Amendment for that object, to a bill from the House of Representatives was adopted— The penal bill was further postponed— In Executive business, Mr: Bradley moved a Resolution to ask the President, for the rejected Treaty with G. Britain, & other papers to judge of the nomination of W. Pinkney as Minister to that Court— It lays for consideration— I was a few minutes in the House of Representatives, where they were debating a bill for annulling public contracts with Members of Congress.— Dined with my wife at Mr: Duvall’s— Evening at a Ball, at Captain Thompson’s— Had some conversation with Mr: Foster, the Secretary of Mr: Erskine; who was very anxious about our Embargo— And with Mr: Dana, on a subject personally respecting myself.

26. There were two messages received this morning from the President— One confidential, enclosing dispatches from Mr: Pinkney at London, and Mr: Armstrong at Paris. The other recommending an immediate levy of six thousand men, in addition to the army, and a corps of twenty-four thousand volunteers.— The Vice-President, not remarking that the first message was marked on the cover Confidential, suffered all the papers to be read without closing the doors— The army message was referr’d to a select Committee— From the tenor of Mr: Pinkney’s dispatches, War with Great Britain appears inevitable.— They were however so satisfactory with respect to his conduct that Mr: Bradley withdrew the motion he had yesterday made to ask for the Treaty & other papers; and the nomination was confirmed by an unanimous vote.— Several Bills were referred to Committees at the second reading.— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to a large party at Mr: R. Smith’s—the Secretary of the Navy.

27.
The Senate adjourned over from yesterday to Monday— This morning at ten I met the Committee on the Bill for extending the time of credit on revenue bonds— Dr: Mitchill—Mr: Smith of Maryland, and myself were the members— We examined the Bill, and agreed it should be reported without amendment; the Chairman, Dr: Mitchill, to consult the Secretary of the Treasury between this and Monday, to enquire whether he would wish any alteration or Amendment of the Bill.— At eleven, met
the Committee on the President’s Army Message of yesterday— The members, are Giles, Sumter, Smith of Maryland, Bradley, and myself— We had some discussion upon the plan recommended in the Message; and agreed upon consulting with the Secretary at War, by personal interview— Then adjourned to Monday morning— I wrote to Governor Sullivan, and enclosed to him a copy of the Army Message— Went into the House of Representatives and heard a debate, on the third embargo Bill, which pass’d to a third reading— Mr: Gardenier’s speech this day last week, on this bill, part of which I heard, has given occasion to some disagreeable occurrences— On Monday, three members of the House, Johnson of Kentucky, Campbell of Tennessee, and Montgomery of Maryland replied to what he had said, by such direct and personal invective, that a challenge of Mr: Campbell, if not also of Mr: Johnson ensued— Mr: White and Mr: Eppes the two seconds, have been making the formal arrangements, and selecting the ground, just beyond the line of the district with much publicity— This morning they all went out, and with such general notice that a crowd of one or two hundred persons, are said to have followed them to the selected spot, where they were finally separated for the present by the magistrates of the District and of the neighbouring County of Maryland— On coming home I found Mr: Boyd very angry at the interference of the magistrates— In the Evening, Mr: Story and Mr: Bacon called and pass’d an hour with us below— Mr: Ellis, a young Gentleman from New-York was also here.

28. Heard Mr: M’Cormick at the Capitol. The weather being fine the house was remarkably well fill’d— I paid a visit to judge Cushing and his Lady at Stelle’s. Catherine and Adelaide Johnson went with me— I then walk’d home with them to Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: and Mrs: Boyd spent the Evening with us— I began a letter to my father, but could not finish it.

29. Met at ten this morning, Mr: Giles’s army message Committee— The Secretary at War attended, and gave such explanations of the plan as he supposed proper— He took offence at some remarks of Mr: Bradley upon it— We agreed however to report the Bill for raising immediately, six thousand men, and Mr: Giles accordingly reported it.— There was little other business done in Senate, and they adjourned very early.— I was a short time in the House of Representatives, where they were passing a Bill for selling Arms to the States— Mr: Erskine, Mr: Rose, and their families, with some other Company spent the Evening and supp’d at Mr: Hellen’s— I received a letter from my father.
Day. As the last Month.
